head.title: Elegy VIII.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 29-31.

l.emph: Curse the sad fortune that detains thy Fair.

epigraph.bibl: Shenstone.22 William Shenstone, The Works in Verse and Prose, vol.1, ed. Dodsley (1764-1765).

lg.l: And now the noon has short’ned ev’ry shade,

The promis’d hour that Delia33 Name of Artemis or Diana, allegedly born in the island of Delos. Citing Tibullus, Maurice Scêve (1510-64) and Samuel Daniel (1562-1619), Alastair Fowler argues that Delia was often used to denote purity. See Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 44. would be here;
Say what detains the sweet tormenting maid,
Ah, will you, Delia, ever be sincere?
Each fanning breeze, that moves the bloomy spray,
Would whisper hope and dissipate my fear;
It seems to tell me, Delia’s on her way,
And now, methinks, her gentle steps I hear.
Again deceiv’d, I take my rural reed,
To pass the time, and play some simple strain;
Again, I bid the moments fly with speed,
Now hope revives, now vanishes again.
Enrag’d with love, I cry, perhaps, ev’n now,
Some rival youth the lovely maid infolds,
While Delia, mindful to perform her vow,
Offended struggles to elude his holds.
Then blame my fate, that gave a nymph so fair,
A nymph by whom each am’rous youth is fir’d,
Again resign my sorrows to the air,
To think my nymph’s by ev’ry swain admired.
Now, sad, I wander by the mazy rill,
Or pull the blossoms from the spreading tree;
Ah vain amusements, I’m unhappy still,
For what are these, my Delia, wanting thee.
Ye little birds, that hop from bush to bush,
O how I murmur at your happy states;
You have no care, no unrewarded wish,
No anxious longing for your absent mates.
No rival will with-hold the constant dove,
No other bird the linnet will detain;
But see, I languish, for my absent love,
And eager wish, but ev’ry wish is vain.
